content: The Traumatic Brain Injury Reauthorization Act of 2014, also known as the CDC Programs for Prevention and Surveillance of Traumatic Brain Injury, amends sections of the Public Health Service Act to update references and authorize appropriations for the prevention and treatment of traumatic brain injuries. The Traumatic Brain Injury Reauthorization Act of 2014 authorizes $6,564,000 for fiscal years 2015 through 2019 for projects related to traumatic brain injury under the Public Health Service Act. Amendments include updating references and funding allocations for prevention and treatment programs. The Traumatic Brain Injury Reauthorization Act of 2014 requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to develop a plan for better coordination of Federal activities related to traumatic brain injury within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The plan will review current interagency coordination efforts, identify areas for improved coordination between relevant Federal agencies and programs, and focus on services for individuals with traumatic brain injury. The Traumatic Brain Injury Reauthorization Act of 2014 mandates the Secretary of Health and Human Services to create a plan for better coordination of Federal activities related to traumatic brain injury. The plan will address recommendations from the Public Health Service Act, incorporate stakeholder feedback, and be submitted to Congress. Additionally, there will be a review of brain injury management in children by the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in consultation with the Director of the National Institutes of Health, will review scientific evidence on brain injury management in children, including school and athletic activity restrictions. Results will be submitted to relevant Senate and House committees within 2 years of the Act's enactment.
